course.subject: ELEC
course.name: Electromagnetics: From Wireless to Photonic Applications
course.description: This area course introduces applied electromagnetics from fundamentals to applications. Topics include: Gauss', Faraday's and Ampere's laws; electrostatics and magnetostatics; Maxwell's equations; electromagnetic plane wave propagation; transmission lines; radiation and antenna fundamentals; light wave fundamentals. Students will also acquire hands-on experience to electromagnetics through laboratory sessions.
course.prerequisites: (MATH 2011 OR MATH 2023) AND MATH 2351 AND PHYS 1114

reviews.author: garbage
reviews.title: Essential for an EE student (imo).
reviews.comment_content:
One important thing to mention in the beginning is that among EE degrees offered by most of the institutions around the world, electromagnetics is one of the most important major requirements (analogous to COMP3711 for CS students). Among the EE degrees of local institutions in Hong Kong, EE offered by UST is the only degree that does not require students to complete electromagnetics. (HKU, CUHK, CityU, PolyU all require their EE students to take electromagnetics. )

Therefore, TAKE THIS COURSE if you want to do an EE master or PhD. It is possible that some PG schools will reject you RIGHT AWAY as soon as they figure out you have not taken this course or ELEC3400. If you want to do IC design (digital or analog), microelectronics or optics and photonics stream, this is even MORE likely to happen.

Tentative list of topics for 13 weeks:
1. Introduction, Vector algebra, Coordinate systems and transformations
2. Vector calculus, Gradient, Divergence and Curl operators, Divergence’s and Stokes’ theorems, Vector fields
3. Electrostatic Fields, Coulomb’s Law, Gauss’ Law, Electric Potential, Electrostatic Energy
4. Electric Field in Material Space, Conductors and Dielectrics, Continuity Equation, Boundary Conditions
5. Resistance and Capacitance, Poisson’s and Laplace’s Equations, Electrostatic Boundary Value Problem (optional)
6. Magnetostatic Fields, Biot-Savart’s law, Ampere’s Law, Magnetic Vector Potential, Magnetic Forces, Magnetic Dipoles, Magnetization, Magnetic Energy, Magnetic Materials
7. Maxwell’s Equations, Displacement Current, Time-Harmonic Fields
8. Electromagnetic Wave Propagation, Plane Waves, Poynting Vector, Reflection of plane waves at normal incidence, Standing waves, Light wave propagation
9. Transmission Lines, Parameters and Equations, Input Impedance, Standing-wave ratio, Power

Actually this course only covers 1-8 due to the limit of the length of one semester.
Calculus IS THE KEY. The most difficult part is not solving the integrals, the most difficult part is how to come up with the BEST INTEGRAL in the BEST COORDINATES.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is very detailed. You don't need to worry that you cannot grasp the course material at all since the professor is very nice who would go over the same part of the lecture again if he finds us having difficult understanding. If you ask him questions through emails, he would send you a long and detailed reply, making sure that you understand inside out.
reviews.comment_grading:
80% homework (8 assignments in total)
20% quizzes (4 quizzes in total)
15% optional project (bonus)

Don't worry about the grade. It would not be bad because there are less than 20 people in this course. Overall 91% and got an A.
reviews.comment_workload: Manageable since there is no midterm or final exam. Make sure to revise the materials once a week to catch up. (You would be forced to go over them when you start handling the assignments anyway. )

reviews.author: sgargaa
reviews.title: Interesting course
reviews.comment_content: The content is not that hard if you attend classes and simply go through the lecture notes once. The lecture notes are pretty great and pretty helpful.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor was good and so was the TA. The lectures were not so boring.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading was absolute and there were two midterms for 20% each, a final for 40%, 3 labs for 5% combined and 12 homework assignments that need to be hand-written and submitted almost every Monday for 15%. Since the homework assignments were due almost every Monday evening, it was a good way to study throughout the semester. The latter half of the course got hard especially with Smith charts and stuff. But then again, the course was absolute graded so not that bad.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload was reasonable given that this is a 4-credit 3000-level course. I will recommend taking it.

reviews.author: Oscar1628
reviews.title: Essential course stepping into EM & Optical field
reviews.comment_content:
This course is important for gaining the foundation in Electromagnetc (EM) and Optical studies. Strictly speaking, it should be classified as the combination of the studies in the field of phys and elec.

Starting from the fundamental concepts such as vector algebra and three types of coordinate systems (cartesian, cyclindrical and spherical) required for subsequential calculations, this course cover in-depth topics including the introduction of electric and magnetic field (Divergence Theorem, Stokes' Theorem, Gauss's Law, Ampere's Circuital Law), the scope of material on E & M field phenomena (Continuity Equation, Relaxation Time, E/M Dipole moment, etc), and eventually, the four complete Maxwell equations expressing in terms of time and space (i.e. -iwt & kr, plane wave propagation, Power E x H, complex intrinsic impedence, loss angle, etc).

* As light is a form of EM waves, it is recommened to have solid understanding of the skills covered in this course before your journey into the studies of optics. For an example, they are important when performing calculations related to light diffraction and interference


If you have a strong interest on the topics, it is crucial to have an effective time management. It is not recommened to take the course alongside with other high workload courses, as it requires your effort to complete assignments and review of the lecture material.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Regared as one of the best professors with good teaching skills.

Most of the time we get stucks about the concepts in other courses, which is the key determinant to your performance. Yet, Prof. Poon is kind of an export that could clearly explain all the concepts covered in the course. Sometimes, he also teaches some additional contents, like the way of how to derive an equation, to reinforce our understanding to particular concepts. Therefore, it is always recommend to attend all his lectures, and you can learn effectively and achieve more.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Scheme for 22-23 Spring:
  40% Assignments
  20% Quizzes
  10% Labs
  40% Final exam

There are more than one quizes, but are simple and required to finish them within limited time.

Labs are also simple and fun. Again, make sure you attend the classes, you can get relative hints and good concepts to understand the lab requirement.

Assignments: (written in the workload session)

* No need to worry about the Grading, if you attend all the classes and willing to spend your time to do the review of materials and exercises. I believe you always have the opportunities to touch A grade. Anyway, it is much important of what you learnt from the course.
reviews.comment_workload:
As I have mentioned previously, any absence of lectures requires extra efforts to catch up the materials, Prof Poon could give you a quick and comprehensive review of any topics, please always attend the classes and listen attentively, you are promised to obtain all the key concepts of EM studies.

Assignments are released every one to two weeks. It is simple if you have attended the lectures, otherwise it is still managable but time-wasting to finish them.

It is appreciated that Prof. Poon have prepared a plenty of practice examples and tutorial notes by the end of each topic. The materials are always accessable and useful for your quizs and final exam preparation.

The overall workload is relatively high compared to other elec courses with the credits of 4.

The professor is the nicest guy I ever seen in HKUST. He remember everyone's name and quiz/homework scores, he really cares everyone and gives warm encouragement. If there is A+ range, I'll choose A+ range for this section.

His teaching is in clear logic and won't make you feel boring during lectures.

Everybody knows some professors even don't know what they are teaching about in this university, they can not even provide an answer. to your question. But Professor POON answers any question clearly and patiently.

This professor is really an expert.You may also find opportunities to do research with him if you are interested about photonics.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grade haven't released yet.I believe it's fair. I'll put a A here and update it later.
40% HW
20% Quizzes
10% Labs
40% Final exam

Although you know your own scores, he won't release mean and SD on Canvas. Maybe the professor want you focus on content itself instead of 'grading'.
To see your final exam scores, you may reach him in person in his office.
Is that a new trend among ECE professors? My instructor from other course to the same thing. Maybe they want to take care of students more in person.
reviews.comment_workload:
I have to give the workload a C,for following three reasons
1.In total 7 homework, each contains 10-11 questions requires you do that really carefully. The period between release date and end date is just one week.
2.The quizzes. Despite finishing 7 hw, you have to prepare quizzes in between, which is quite stressful
3.The lecture contents are too much and difficult for engineer students. Nobody can really understand it even to 90%.
